title: How to Play the Cosmos Game

steps.headline: Ask another person to choose a number.
steps.description: This can be a friend, part of a group, or a person you're trying to confuse. You can ask them for a number between one and ten to start, or, if you're playing with more than one other person, allow them to choose any number.

steps.headline: Count the number of letters in the number that they have chosen.
steps.description: Tell them that that number is cosmos. For example, they might choose six. Since the word "six" has three letters in it, three is cosmos. Tell them, "Six is three and three is cosmos."

steps.headline: If you're doing this in a group, involve everyone.
steps.description: Form a circle and have each person chose a number and find out its Cosmos. See who can guess the pattern first. When playing this game in a group, it's much more fun to go to higher numbers than 10.

steps.headline: Ask another person to choose a number, just as in the method above.
steps.description: Again, it can be helpful to restrict them to a number between one and ten, but it can also be more fun to let them choose any number.

steps.headline: Count the number of letters in the number that they chose.
steps.description: If they chose six, which has three letters in them, the new number will be three. Tell them, "Six is three."

steps.headline: Count the number of letters in the new number.
steps.description: If the new number above was three (because "six" has three letters), this becomes the old number, and the new number will become the number of letters in the old number. Since "three" has five letters, the new number is five. Tell them, "Three is five."

steps.headline: Repeat until you get to four.
steps.description: Since five, the new number from above, has four letters, the new number is four. Say, "Five is four." Then, since you've reached four, you can stop.

steps.headline: Say, "Four is cosmos."
steps.description: The word "four" has four letters in it, so if you didn't stop here, you'd be saying "four is four" forever. Instead, simply say "four is cosmos," and have you friends try to figure out why four is cosmos - it's the only number that works this way. The whole round for this example would work like this: the other person chooses six, so you say, "Six is three, and three is five, and five is four, and four is cosmos." The starting number doesn't matter; this will work with any number they give you, even numbers above ten.

steps.headline: Repeat with more starting numbers and more people until they get it.
steps.description: Make them figure out why four is cosmos and how the whole trick works. Make them do it for you before you tell them if they're right.
